q: What are some ways to ease toe pain?
a: You can rest and elevate your foot, apply ice packs, wear comfortable shoes, use painkillers, buddy strap a broken toe, and try gentle stretching exercises.

q: How long should I put an ice pack on my toe?
i: You should put an ice pack on your toe for up to 20 minutes every 2 to 3 hours.
a: You should put an ice pack on your toe for up to 20 minutes every 2 to 3 hours.

q: What should I do if my toe pain doesn't improve?
a: If your toe pain doesn't improve, it's recommended to see a GP for further evaluation and advice.

q: Can a pharmacist help with toe pain?
a: Yes, a pharmacist can advise you on the best painkiller to take, insoles and pads for your shoes, and treatments for common skin and nail problems.

q: Are the exercises in the video suitable for everyone?
a: The exercises in the video are suitable for most people in good health with a reasonable level of fitness. If you have any health concerns, it's best to consult a healthcare professional before trying them.

q: When should I see a GP for toe pain?
a: You should see a GP for toe pain if it is stopping you from doing normal activities, getting worse or recurring, or if it hasn't improved after treating it at home for 2 weeks.

q: What should I do if I have severely broken my big toe?
a: If you have severely broken your big toe and are experiencing severe pain, difficulty moving your toes, or tingling/loss of sensation in your foot, you should go to an urgent treatment center or A&E for immediate medical attention.

q: What are some possible causes of toe pain?
a: Some possible causes of toe pain are exercising too much, wearing tight shoes, ingrown toenails, bunions, Raynaud's or chilblains, broken toes, and gout.

q: Should I see a GP if my toe pain doesn't improve in 2 weeks?
a: Yes, if your toe pain doesn't improve within 2 weeks, it's recommended to see a GP for further evaluation and treatment.

q: What should I do if I'm not sure what's causing my toe pain?
a: If you're not sure what's causing your toe pain, you can follow the advice on this page and if the pain does not get better in 2 weeks, it's best to see a GP for further assessment.

q: What are some ways to ease toe pain yourself?
a: You can rest and elevate your foot, apply ice packs, wear comfortable shoes, use painkillers, buddy strap a broken toe, and try gentle stretching exercises.

q: Can a pharmacist help with toe pain?
a: Yes, a pharmacist can advise you on the best painkiller to take, provide insoles and pads for your shoes, and recommend treatments for common skin and nail problems. They can also help you decide if you need to see a GP.

q: Are there exercises that can reduce toe pain?
a: Yes, there are exercises that can help reduce toe pain. It is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional before trying them, especially if you have any health problems or concerns.

q: When should I see a GP for toe pain?
a: You should see a GP if the pain in your toe is severe, if it's interfering with your normal activities, if it's getting worse or recurring, or if it hasn't improved after treating it at home for 2 weeks.

q: What are the possible causes of toe pain?
a: Common causes of toe pain include exercising too much, wearing tight shoes, ingrown toenails, bunions, Raynaud's or chilblains, broken toes, and gout.

q: When should I go to an urgent treatment centre or A&E for toe pain?
a: You should go to an urgent treatment centre or A&E if you have badly hurt your big toe, if you're experiencing severe pain, if you have tingling or loss of sensation in your foot, if your toe is pointing at an odd angle, or if you have difficulty moving your toes or walking.

q: What should I do if I have a mild to moderate toe pain?
a: If you have mild to moderate toe pain, you can follow the advice on this page and see a GP if the pain doesn't improve in 2 weeks.

q: What should I do if I have severe toe pain?
a: If you have severe toe pain that is always there and interfering with your daily activities, you should seek immediate medical attention at an urgent treatment centre or A&E.

q: What if I'm not sure what's causing my toe pain?
a: If you're unsure about the cause of your toe pain, you can follow the advice on this page and see a GP if the pain doesn't improve in 2 weeks.

q: What should I do if I have a broken toe?
a: If you suspect a broken toe, you can buddy strap it by placing a small piece of cotton wool or gauze between your sore toe and the next toe, and using tape to loosely strap it up. However, don't do this for a big toe or a badly broken toe.
